greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Distribution of maximum inversion table entry.
comment: T(n,k) = number of permutations p of [n] such that max(p(i)-i)=k. Example: T(3,0)=1 because for p=123 we have max(p(i)-i)=0; T(3,1)=3 because for p=132, 213, 231 we have max(p(i)-i) =1; T(3,2)=2 because for p=312, 321 we have max(p(i)-i)=2. - _Emeric Deutsch_, Nov 12 2004
reference: R. Sedgewick and Ph. Flajolet, "An Introduction to the Analysis of Algorithms", Addison-Wesley, 1996, ISBN 0-201-40009-X, table 6.10 (page 356)
link: Alois P. Heinz, Rows n = 1..141, flattened
E. Deutsch, I. M. Gessel and D.Callan, Problem 10634: Permutation Parameters with the Same Distribution, Amer. Math. Monthly, 107 (2000), 567-568.
formula: T(n, k)=k!(k+1)^(n-k) - (k-1)!k^(n-k+1) if 0<k<=n; T(n, 0)=1. - _Emeric Deutsch_, Nov 12 2004
maple: T:=proc(n,k) if k>0 and k<=n then k!*(k+1)^(n-k)-(k-1)!*k^(n-k+1) elif k=0 then 1 else 0 fi end: TT:=(n,k)->T(n,k-1): matrix(10,10,TT);
mathematica: Table[T[n, k], {n, 1, 10}, {k, 0, n - 1}] // Flatten (* _Jean-François Alcover_, May 03 2017 *)
xref: Columns and diagonals give A000225, A018927, A056182, A000142, A056197.
results.author: _Wouter Meeussen_, Aug 05 2000
ext: More terms from Larry Reeves (larryr(AT)acm.org), Oct 03 2000
